title.narrative: Cooperative Threat Reduction Program: Audits and Examinations

description.narrative: Audits and Examinations are used to ensure that assistance provided is accounted for and used efficiently and effectively for its intended purpose with Kazakhstan, Georgia, Moldova, Albania, and Uzbekistan. In Ukraine, A&Es may be performed until expiration of the U.S.-Ukraine CTR Umbrella Agreement. Through FY 2006, the U.S. has conducted 170 A&Es in the recipient states.

receiver-org.narrative: U.S. Government - Department of Defense

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of Defense, Cooperative Threat Reduction Account

receiver-org.narrative: U.S. Government - Department of Defense

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of Defense, Cooperative Threat Reduction Account

title.narrative: Cooperative Threat Reduction Program: Threat Reduction Engagement

description.narrative: The Cooperative Threat Reduction (CTR) program is designed to help the countries of the former Soviet Union address the environmental, health, and related issues after nuclear, chemical and biological weapons were transferred to Russia. The program also provides retraining of scientists and engineer for peaceful and commercial pursuits.

title.narrative: Global Train and Equip Program - Counter Illicit Drug Trafficking: Albania, Bosnia, Bulgaria, Greece, Macedonia, Romania, and Serbia

description.narrative: To conduct or support programs providing training and equipment to national security forces of foreign countries for the purpose of building capacity of partner nations. The Defense Security Cooperation Agency (DSCA) provides program management. Country teams work through DoD geographic Combatant Commands (COCOMs).

sector.narrative: Stabilization Operations and Security Sector Reform

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of Defense, Operation and Maintenance, Defense-Wide

description.narrative: The Eastern European Training Initiative (ETI) provides training for Eastern European national military forces in the course of multilateral exercises and pays the incremental expenses incurred by a country as the direct result of participation in such training. Incremental expenses are expenses incurred by the operating forces, such as fuel and ammunition, and not normal personnel expenses such as pay and per diem.

receiver-org.narrative: U.S. Government - Department of Defense

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of Defense, Operation and Maintenance, Defense-Wide

receiver-org.narrative: U.S. Government - Department of Defense

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of Defense, Operation and Maintenance, Defense-Wide

description.narrative: The Inter-European Air Base Defense (IEABD) course is intended for personnel (both officer and enlisted) assigned as current or future Air Base Defense or Security Forces personnel. It will provide students with a working knowledge of air base defense theories and practices to align NATO and Partnership for Peace allies with Agile Combat Employment (ACE) war-fighting functions. Topics will include defense-in-depth planning, armed response and air base entry control, operating in a variety of field environment conditions and challenges, emergency planning and response recovery operations, and developing plans, policies, procedures, and instructions to implement air base defense and security programs. The course will be delivered by subject matter experts training personnel through in-resident informal lectures, guided discussion, and practical exercises.

description.narrative: The Inter-European Aviation Safety Program Management (IEASPM) Course is intended for personnel (both officer and enlisted) assigned to current or future Flight Safety Officer (FSO) positions. It will provide students with a working knowledge of an aviation mishap prevention.program. Course graduates will be capable of administrating an aircraft mishap prevention.program to include: bird/wildlife aircraft strike hazard (BASH), midair collision avoidance.(MACA), hazardous air traffic reports (HATRs), hazard reporting, inspections, airfield safety, and.disaster response. In addition, the course will also address concepts, methodologies, and best.practices in the area of Risk Management (RM). Each course incorporates visits to active airfields.to observe aviation mishap prevention programs.

description.narrative: The Inter-European Basic Instructor Course (IEBIC) is designed to prepare mid-grade enlisted and junior officers (OF-2) to serve as instructors capable of tailoring delivery methods and lessons of instruction based on the needs of their student population. IEBIC consists of lessons adopted from the Theories and Principles of Adult Education (TPAE) and the Enlisted Professional Military Education Instructor Course (EPMEIC) curriculums. Curriculum delivery is focused on achieving higher levels of learning through deliberate application of instructor skill sets. The course focuses on effective teaching techniques, including classroom management, feedback/assessment, and delivery skills. Instructional methods taught in the course include lectures, guided discussions, case studies, gamification, and experiential learning. All classes are developed using established educational theory, to which the students are also exposed. The course includes practical application and focuses on developing instructors through mentorship and actionable feedback.

participating-org.narrative: U.S. Government - Department of the Air Force

description.narrative: The Inter-European Noncommissioned Officer Academy (IENCOA) course (5 weeks) is designed to develop enlisted personnel for increased roles and responsibilities. It prepares NCOs, SNCOs, and Warrant Officers to operate on Commanders intent and drive mission success in ambiguous, complex operating environments. The curriculum focuses on four core attributes of a professional enlisted member: (1) Military Professional, (2) Operational Airman, (3) Unit Manager, and (4) Managerial Communicator. IENCOA emphasizes personal, team, and organizational leadership, equipping its students with theory, doctrine, and practical experiences which empower them to seek and capitalize on leadership opportunities. IENCOA graduates are able to communicate effectively, both formally and informally, through oral and written methods, conveying their ideas and instructions logically in a manner that informs, motivates, and inspires subordinates and peers alike. Furthermore, IENCOA fosters student interdependence through multiple team building and problem solving tasks/exercises. This cooperation and cross-cultural experience reflects the coalition framework exemplified in todays global security environment. Finally, IENCOA students come from a collective pool of NATO and Partnership for Peace nations. This blend of multi-cultural experience enhances the guided discussion delivery method that comprises the majority of in-class curriculum.

description.narrative: The Inter-European Professional Development Seminar (IEPDS) is designed to develop non-commissioned officers, senior non-commissioned officers, warrant officers and junior officers in a blended officer/enlisted environment to prepare them for increased leadership roles and responsibilities. The curriculum is developed from a sampling of courses offered in the 5-week IESOS and IENCOA Professional Military Education courses. After completing this course, graduates will have acquired and practiced new leadership skills such as problem solving, critical thinking, and teambuilding. These new skillsets will help them develop as leaders and as team members. Course activities will challenge students to apply newly learned principles.

participating-org.narrative: U.S. Government - Department of the Air Force

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of the Air Force, Operations and Maintenance

description.narrative: The Inter-European Squadron Officer School (IESOS) (5 weeks) is designed to prepare junior officers (OF-2) to operate on Commanders intent and prepare them for increased leadership roles and responsibilities. The curriculum is developed by the Squadron Officer School at Maxwell Air Force Base under the strict guidelines set forth by the United States Air Force Air University. After completing this course, graduates will have acquired and practiced new leadership skills, such as problem-solving, critical thinking, teambuilding, and mentoring techniques. These new skillsets will help them lead and motivate personnel to accomplish the mission, both at their home units and abroad in the joint environment. Course activities challenge each student to apply newly learned principles successfully and to influence group dynamics, cohesion, and effectiveness in a positive manner. IESOS is a course for officers, who had or will complete their own Air Force academic requirements for promotion to the rank of major, or as a required course for promotion. This course includes the following blocks of instruction: administration, extracurricular activities, profession of arms, warfare, leadership, communication, and international security studies.

These new skillsets will help them lead and motivate personnel to accomplish the mission, both at their home units and abroad in the joint environment. Course activities challenge each student to apply newly learned principles successfully and to influence group dynamics, cohesion, and effectiveness in a positive manner. IESOS is a course for officers, who had or will complete their own Air Force academic requirements for promotion to the rank of major, or as a required course for promotion. This course includes the following blocks of instruction: administration, extracurricular activities, profession of arms, warfare, leadership, communication, and international security studies.

description.narrative: The Inter-European Squadron Officer School (IESOS) (5 weeks) is designed to prepare junior officers (OF-2) to operate on Commanders intent and prepare them for increased leadership roles and responsibilities. The curriculum is developed by the Squadron Officer School at Maxwell Air Force Base under the strict guidelines set forth by the United States Air Force Air University. After completing this course, graduates will have acquired and practiced new leadership skills, such as problem-solving, critical thinking, teambuilding, and mentoring techniques. These new skillsets will help them lead and motivate personnel to accomplish the mission, both at their home units and abroad in the joint environment. Course activities challenge each student to apply newly learned principles successfully and to influence group dynamics, cohesion, and effectiveness in a positive manner. IESOS is a course for officers, who had or will complete their own Air Force academic requirements for promotion to the rank of major, or as a required course for promotion. This course includes the following blocks of instruction: administration, extracurricular activities, profession of arms, warfare, leadership, communication, and international security studies.

title.narrative: Inter-European Tactical Combat Casualty Care Course (IETCCC)

description.narrative: The Inter-European Tactical Combat Casualty Care (IETCCC) course is primarily designed for combat Emergency Medical Service military personnel, including medics, corpsmen, and para-rescue personnel deploying in support of combat operations. The course is also applicable to non-medical military personnel and teaches medical first responder skills appropriate for all military members likely to engage in direct combat. The course introduces evidence-based, life-saving techniques and strategies for providing trauma care on the battlefield. The course includes classroom academics, demonstrations, and application in an interactive environment using medical simulators. Additionally, the final portion of the course is conducted as a field exercise, where students demonstrate tactical casualty care skills learned in the course in a simulated combat environment.

title.narrative: Proliferation Security Initiative - Mediteranean Initiative Working Group

description.narrative: The Proliferation Security Initiative (PSI) is an international cooperative effort to stop trafficking in Weapons of Mass Destruction (WMD), their delivery systems, and related materials to and from state and non-state actors of proliferation concern. DoD is the U.S. Governments operational lead for the PSI and works closely with other departments/agencies to conduct and participate in PSI exercises, workshops, training events, meetings and other activities. These activities demonstrate the commitment of participants to the PSI Statement of Interdiction Principles, test national capabilities to conduct air, ground, and maritime interdictions and increase understanding of PSI globally and within geographic regions.
